Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 08:31PM AmyR wrote: I can't take over the counter supplements because most mess with your immune system. My neuromuscular disease and my Lupus etc are autoimmune which means my own immune systems over-active. It went haywire and started attacking my own body. I already have to take more than 30 pills. The MG can effect swallowing so that gets old at times. My 14yo dd's first boyfriend dumped her by text message a while ago. They hadn't had any problems. It seemed out of the blue.
Posts.Title: emotional roller coaster... AmyR Lavender250

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 09:25PM AmyR wrote: I've decided to quit reading any more about bc until after my biopsy. I have become way too hyper-focused and it is feeding my anxiety. I am going to do everything in my power to turn my health and thoughts over to God. I am praying for Him to give insight to my doctors. One thing I think that I'm missing that is really important to me is speaking to a doc who knows about breast issues. As it is, I have been researching and it isn't specific to my exact findings so I can only guess. Guessing never takes me anywhere good. I thank you all so much and am hopeful that I can distract the next few days. I will plan to pop back in after my bx on Tues.
Posts.Title: emotional roller coaster... AmyR Lavender250

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2011 12:34PM AmyR wrote: Had my stereotactic biopsies. I'd had one a couple of years ago so I didn't think much of it. This time was much more difficult because the two spots they wanted to biopsy were almost against my chest wall. I am large breasted and two docs and the nurse kept trying to pull my breast and shoulder into the hole. I have muscle and joint problems so it was difficult to bare for almost 3 hours. They took 28 core needle biopsies. They checked to make sure multiple parts of the two calcifications were in the samples. They decided not to biopsy the lymoh nodes unless I have to have surgery. The fellow (doc) promised to call me ASAP himself this time rather than waiting for the originally ordering physician to sign off. He said I may know in 48 hours. I want to know beforebthe weekend even though it won't really change anything.
Posts.Title: emotional roller coaster... AmyR Lavender250

Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 06:59PM AmyR wrote: Thanks! I was able to take a nap and it helped a little because I haven't been sleeping. Last night got to me because my son was upset about something else and he kept saying things couldn't get worse and I just kept thinking if he only knew... I do think that we'd get through this. It was tough when I was dx'ed with the neuromuscular disease and horrible when I broke my back, but we made it through. We will deal with this no matter what. I've been through a lot of tough times in my life, but God has never left me to be alone.
Posts.Title: emotional roller coaster... AmyR Lavender250

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2011 11:17PM AmyR wrote: Ok, so my attempt to steer clear of here didn't work at all, but I do think I'm at least in a better space in my head for now. I am worried. I dread the possibility of a result that may mean big changes to my health and daily living, but I will cope with whatever results come through. I've been through some pretty rough times and while I sometimes think of myself as fragile, I will make it through this if I have to. I guess I needed to spend a few days having an internal "emotional barf-o-ramma" as I call it. I go for my biopsies at 7:50 in the morning. I'm letting a friend take me this time instead of going alone. I couldn't get in touch with the ordering physician of test because I had no idea who it was. Finally had a nurse look it up and I've never met this person. I think a HUGE part of my anxiety has come from not being able to talk to a doctor about all of this. I lost insurance 8 months ago because my cobra ran out and I'm waiting for disability to kick in. I decided to call my gp that I'd seen for 17 years prior to this and she has been on vacation. I requested all of my images and reports be sent to her. She is back from vacation tomorrow so I'm hoping she will call me tomorrow after my biopsy to tell me what she thinks. I've had both lumps and calcifications. They are scary in different ways. When I've had lumps, I've known they were there and could see them etc. The weird calcifications are so abstract and they are like some weird thing I can only try to imagine. I really thought that this mammogram was going to be totally fine because the last one had been. Finding the report on my own was about the worst way I could have found out because it left my mind open to imagine the very worst things ever. I had myself in surgery on a ventilator (due to side effects from my neuromuscular disease and surgery), my kids were living with my abusive ex, they were ready to flip out, my breasts were looped off crudely, and somehow despite the respirator, I was throwing up profusely, while I sported six scraggly long hairs from my head. Not a pretty site, huh? Lol Oh the places our heads can take us!
Posts.Title: emotional roller coaster... AmyR Lavender250

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2011 04:17AM AmyR wrote: Martygra, I am praying you find out good news today! I am really sorry you had to wait over the long weekend. I have my biopsy this morning and I've changed my prayers from "God, PLEASE don't let me have CANCER!" to "God, you are already in charge of my life. Please help me get through whatever paths things go down next." The black and white thinking that I live or die a grueling death was making me totally crazy! I will be HUGELY relieved if this comes back as malignant, but I'm trying hard not to look at this as the end of my world.

I am terrified that my biopsy will be malignant and also worried that it won't be because I can't stand the thought of going through this over and over. Then I feel horribly selfish about what it would do to my teenaged kids. My daughter is already clingy. I am 43 and have had other breast issues and a biopsy (on the other breast). There are a number of new watch things in addition to the two clusters of calcifications and lymph nodes that are going to be biopsied. I read there is a 30% chance that it can be abnormal, but not cancerous. What do they do about that? Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 09:42PM - edited Sep 5, 2011 11:17PM by AmyR Just popped in to say that the stress everyone was feeling in my house got to be too much so I sat down with my 17yo son and his girlfriend today and without going into details I told them that I have been stressed because I'm going in on Tuesday for a biopsy to rule out breast cancer. My son questioned why I hadn't told him right away and I told him I wanted to.protect him from worry and stress. I later told my 14yo dd. I didn't mention the big C, but did tell her I was having a breast biopsy on Tues. I told her I'd had one before and she didn't seem too swathed. I'm just relieved that the big black secret is at least partially out of the bag.

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2011 09:12PM AmyR wrote: Cycle-path, I think when I first came here, the reports and such had me so scared that even thought the stats said that the biopsy rate was 29%, I was certain that I was in the 20% and that I was going under with the Titanic in the next six months or so because I had a close friend who died at 33 from an aggressive form of breast cancer. I have known a whole lot of other women who have had breast cancer and done super well and gone on to where I really don't even think of them when I think of breast cancer. I think it is so helpful that you show people here that breast cancer like my 33yo friend's is rare. Boards like this are typically where people are struggling hang out. So often people do encounter the freak exceptions and I think you are really great about pointing out that those are so incredibly unlikely. The truth is that I may or may not have breast cancer. I find out tomorrow, but I'm so incredibly relieved that I have come to the point where I don't feel like if it is, it is a death sentence or the worst possible thing that could happen. I have a lot of significant health problems that could complicate a diagnosis so I was freaking about that too. I was taking each situation and figuring that I would be the person who would have the problem. That was so unhealthy. I couldn't sleep. I couldn't eat. I couldn't do the basics. The interesting thing is that not one single part of my medical situation has really changed. I have to believe that no matter what the results are, I will be part of the 80% that really does really well.

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 07:30PM AmyR wrote: I can't begin to tell you how much your support has meant to me the past couple of weeks or so. I realize that this board is mainly "staffed" by women who are going through breast cancer treatment themselves. I am sure you get pretty similar freaked out posts a lot, but I was made to feel like you were talking to just me each and every time I posted. It didn't take long for me to realize that the women here didn't respond out of some sort of duty or with some pat answer. I know if my results had not been good news, you would have stood beside me. I am thankful that today you are celebrating with me. I will continue to pray for all of you through your cancer and healing journeys. Be well! Amy
Posts.Title: My Good News AmyR AmyR

Posts.Content: AmyR wrote: I have had a number of suspicious mamogram and have even had a biopsy before. The thing that has me winged out this time is that in addition to the suspicious 9mm leasion, the lymph nodes near it look abnormal. I have a cluster of whatever shaped microcalcifications and in the middle of it is the 9mm thing... I have a more detailed mammogram and ultrasound on Monday, but as soon as I read the results of the mammo, my stomach sank. I have a horrible state insurance and my doctor didn't even call to tell me any of this. I read the test result's in the hospital's Mychart page when I was looking for something else. It told me to call to schedule the follow-up tests. I hate not being able to see my regular doctors. My doc would have NEVER left it for me to read by chance...or wait to have a letter mailed to me weeks later. I feel so alone in all of this. I am a 43yo single mom of two teenagers. They've been through so much the past two and a half years I can't imagine having to tell them anymore bad news. A little over two years ago I was diagnosed with a neuro-muscular disease and then about 8 months later I fell on the ice and fractured my back. I've had to quit the teaching career I loved passionately. My neuro-muscular disease drains all of my energy so I can't even fathom taking on chemotherapy etc. One of my biggest fears though is that if I have to have any major surgery, I could wind up on a ventilator at least for a while. The anesthesia makes the muscles in a MG patient's lungs weak and shut down. The stress of surgery itself is asking for a HUGE flare. I didn't sleep for about 4 days straight once I found out. I tried to Google very scary statistics about breast cancer the next couple and then a couple of days ago, I forced myself to do life. I then was able to sleep at least some. Now I'm waiting until Monday to have the tests so I can wait until the radiologist posts the results so I probably schedule a biopsy after that. I wish they'd just do the biopsy and get it over with! Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: abnormal Mammogram AmyR marie5890

Posts.Content: Aug 29, 2011 07:12PM AmyR wrote: I had been feeling like a run away train last week and didn't even sleep for days. I felt it was all too big and too hard. One night I prayed for God to give me the peace I needed to do my basic life responsibilities the next few days until I knew more. I slept that night and woke up feeling like my alike it was still probable that I have cancer, but that I could do things like put a load of laundry on and other basic stuff. It lifted so much weight and panic. I can't really describe it. This afternoon I had the magnified mammo (what seemed like millions of pics on each both sides) and then the ultrasound of both breasts. I knew when the tech went to get the radiologist to come in to look, it wasn't good. When the radiologist took me into a room and said that there were a couple of masses and the closest lymph nodes that were highly suspicious, I didn't freak out. I guess I knew and I wanted more than anything just to get to the next step with all of this. They wanted to get ne in ASAP for the biopsy, but since they have to do more than one spot, they had to find a double opening. I have it early next Tuesday morning. I am more concerned about the pain of lying flat on a table that long... What if I can't lie still that long? I had a stereotactic biopsy a couple of years ago, but it was on the other side and just on small calcifications. The lymph node abnormalities are what make it feel so much more serious. Amy

Posts.Content: Sep 8, 2011 03:11AM AmyR wrote: A radiologist did both of my stereotactic biopsies. They are usually done in the clinic where mammograms are done. They have the special table and equipment set up there. It's a tad bizarre being lifted up like a car on a hoist and having them work under you while your breast hangs through the table. The actual biopsy doesn't hurt.

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 10:32PM AmyR wrote: Skylar, when I was 25 and had never had kids. I found a lump. Then shortly after that started having milky secretions from my nipples. Freaked me out big time as I had a 31yo friend with bc. When I tried to get pregnant my hormone levels were way off. I had a high proactive level. The fertility doc said I may never conceive. Well, shocking to both of us, I got pregnant despite really low odds. I had to wait until my baby was a few months old to have an MRI of my head. They found a .9 cm military microadenoma. When the nurse called me at school (while I was teaching) to tell me not to worry that I just had a small b9 tumor in my head, I about fell apart. My sister had died of a brain tumor and I was almost indignant that she was so certain it was b9. The doc and pretty much all I have read says that they really are. Most of the time, the only big problems are fertility and that in only rare instances they can press on an optic nerve and require surgery. I'd start by looking to see if there is a free medical clinic in your area. They should be able to help you find resources if they can't help you. First off, I'd ask them to run a blood test for Prolaxtin level. If it is high, it basically means your body is playing a mean trick on you to act like a nursing mom. For a while they just monitored mine with yearly MRI's and labwork. I haven't had any problems or symptoms for a number of years now. Deep breath! The unknown is always scares.
Posts.Title: Should I be even more worried? skylar321 Lowrider54

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2011 10:30AM AmyR wrote: It is so weird to say this out loud, but I think I would just be relieved to know it is cancer and to get going ASAP on getting my breasts removed so the biggest worries would be done and over with. I am thinking if I did lumpectomy, I'd constantly be worries because there are so many places they are watching. The thought of chemo and repeatedly poking is more daunting than the pain of a surgery. I threw up daily and was in and out of the hospital my who pregnancy with my son. I felt like I'd die.

Posts.Content: AmyR wrote: Does the location of the lump or whatever the malignant thing is make a big difference as far as treatment? It just seems like in some instances it would make a huge difference. Because I can't feel these, I hadn't really considered that they were going to biopsy an area that was pretty much against my chest wall. I was reading my own results because I couldn't get a real live doctor to tell me what was going on . Sorry about letting my anger show through again. Anyway, it seems pretty likely that IF this is malignant, they will want to take the whole thing? The doc said that there are two clusters of calcifications. They look big on the magnified mammo, but I think they are around 1cm each more or less. I also don't think I can have radiation due to all of my autoimmune problems so that might impact things. I am REALLY glad that I only have to wait two more days to know what happens next in my life. Log in to post a reply
